choices.text: Decreased extracellular K⁺ → RMP more negative
Increased intracellular K⁺ → RMP more negative
Increased extracellular K⁺ → RMP less negative
Decreased intracellular Na⁺ → RMP less negative

questions.text: A patient presents with muscle weakness and ECG showing peaked T waves. Labs reveal serum K⁺ = 6.5 m Eq /L. Based on the Nernst equation, which of the following best explains the reduced excitability of muscle cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased extracellular K⁺ → RMP less negative

Explanation:

• ↑ extracellular K⁺ → less K⁺ efflux → RMP becomes less negative → inactivates Na⁺ channels → ↓ excitability.

questions.text: A child with hepatosplenomegaly, neurodegeneration, and “cherry-red spot” is found to have accumulation of sphingolipids due to a lysosomal enzyme defect. Which function of lysosomes is impaired here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Autophagic degradation
Explanation:
Lysosomes contain hydrolytic enzymes. Defects (e.g., Tay–Sachs) → accumulation of macromolecules due to impaired degradation.

choices.text: Equal permeability to Na⁺ and K⁺
Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase and selective K⁺ leak

questions.text: Which of the following contributes most to the generation of the resting membrane potential in neurons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase and selective K⁺ leak
Explanation:
• K⁺ leak channels set RMP near –70 mV, close to K⁺ Nernst potential.
• Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase maintains gradient but leak dominates RMP.

questions.text: The presence of plasma proteins that cannot cross capillary membranes leads to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Electrolyte asymmetry across capillaries
Explanation:
Negatively charged non-diffusible proteins attract cations (Na⁺), repelling anions → electrolyte imbalance known as Gibbs–Donnan effect.

questions.text: In a negative feedback system, a high increase in BP has turned out to be a small rise in BP due to baroreceptor activation. This indicates:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

High gain
Explanation:
Gain = correction / error remaining. Large correction (↓HR) for small error (↑BP) → high gain = effective feedback.

questions.text: A patient with heat stroke presents with hot dry skin, confusion, and tachycardia. Which mechanism has failed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Evaporation
Explanation:
Evaporation (sweating) is key in heat loss during hyperthermia. In heat stroke, sweating mechanism fails, leading to dry skin and overheating.

questions.text: A patient with nephrotic syndrome has hypoalbuminemia and edema. What best explains the edema?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Decreased plasma oncotic pressure
Explanation:
↓Albumin → ↓oncotic pull → fluid shifts to interstitium → edema.

questions.text: Before running a race, a sprinter shows increased HR and ventilation without any muscle activity. This anticipatory response is an example of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Feedforward regulation
Explanation:
Feedforward: response triggered by anticipated need (e.g., before actual exertion), not by error.

questions.text: A patient with prolonged PT and a normal aPTT is found to have deficiency of a vitamin K–dependent factor. Which factor is most likely deficient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Factor VII
Explanation:
PT reflects extrinsic pathway, where Factor VII is first to be affected by vitamin K deficiency.

questions.text: A newborn develops hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN) due to Rh incompatibility. Which maternal antibody is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

IgG
Explanation:
Only IgG crosses the placenta. In Rh-negative mothers, anti-D IgG attacks Rh-positive fetal RBCs → HDN.

questions.text: During skeletal muscle contraction, which of the following remains unchanged in length?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A band
Explanation:
• The A band represents the length of thick (myosin) filaments and remains constant during contraction.
• I band and H zone shorten.
• The sarcomere (Z to Z) shortens.

questions.text: A patient with cardiomyopathy has impaired stroke volume due to abnormal ventricular filling. This is best explained by which physiological principle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Length-tension relationship
Explanation:
• Optimal sarcomere length (~2.0–2.2 µm) maximizes actin-myosin overlap → maximal tension.
• In dilated cardiomyopathy, sarcomeres are overstretched → reduced tension.

questions.text: Which sarcomeric protein anchors the thick filament to the Z-line and contributes to passive elasticity in muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

. Titin
Explanation:
• Titin spans from Z-line to M-line, stabilizing myosin and acting like a spring for passive recoil.
• Nebulin is associated with thin filament.
• Dystrophin connects cytoskeleton to ECM (not part of sarcomere proper).

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has calf pseudohypertrophy and Gowers’ sign. The absence of which protein leads to sarcolemma instability in Duchenne muscular dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dystrophin
Explanation:
• Dystrophin links actin to the dystroglycan complex and ECM. Its absence → membrane tears → ↑Ca²⁺ influx → necrosis.
• X-linked recessive mutation.

choices.text: Type I fibers – high mitochondria, slow-twitch
Type IIA fibers – glycolytic, low myoglobin
Type IIx fibers – fatigue-resistant, high myoglobin

questions.text: Which type of skeletal muscle fiber is most active in a 5-km marathon runner compared to a 100-m sprinter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Type I fibers – high mitochondria, slow-twitch
Explanation:
• Endurance (aerobic) uses Type I: red, oxidative, fatigue-resistant.
• Sprint (anaerobic) uses Type IIb / IIx: white, glycolytic, fatigue-prone.

questions.text: When a person holds a heavy object without changing muscle length, which type of contraction occurs in the biceps?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Isometric
Explanation:
• Isometric = no length change, tension increases (e.g., holding a suitcase).
• Isotonic = length changes:
o Concentric (shortening),
o Eccentric (lengthening under load).

questions.text: Tetanus toxin blocks neurotransmission by cleaving which component at inhibitory interneurons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Synaptobrevin (V-SNARE)
Explanation:
• Tetanus toxin targets inhibitory (GABA/glycine) neurons in spinal cord by cleaving V-SNARE (synaptobrevin) → unchecked excitation → spastic paralysis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old smoker has muscle weakness that improves with repeated use. Reflexes are reduced. What is the pathophysiological mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Autoantibodies against presynaptic Ca²⁺ channels

Explanation:
• Lambert–Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS): Ab against presynaptic P/Q-type Ca²⁺ channels → ↓ACh release.
• Improves with use (build-up of Ca²⁺).
• Often paraneoplastic (small cell lung carcinoma).
• MG is postsynaptic → worsens with

questions.text: The graph shown below is a muscle’s mechanical response to increasing stimulus frequency. If the duration from point A to D (single muscle twitch) is 100 ms, what is the minimum stimulation frequency (in Hz) required to produce fused tetanus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

20 Hz
Explanation:
• The time from A to D = one complete muscle twitch duration = 100 milliseconds = 0.1 seconds.
• For fused tetanus, the stimuli must be delivered before the muscle relaxes, i.e., at intervals < twitch duration.
• So, minimum tetanizing frequency =
f = 1 / twitch duration = 1 / 50 msec = 20 Hz

questions.text: A 45-year-old man accidentally touches a hot stove and immediately withdraws his hand, feeling sharp, localized pain followed by a dull, burning sensation. Which of the following fiber types is responsible for conducting the delayed, dull pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

C fibers

questions.text: A patient with damage to Meissner’s corpuscles would most likely experience difficulty perceiving which of the following sensations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fine touch
Explanation:
• Meissner’s corpuscles are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors in glabrous skin, specialized for fine touch and texture.
• Pacinian – vibration; Merkel – pressure; Free nerve endings – pain/temp.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory modalities is conveyed by the dorsal column–medial lemniscus pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Proprioception and vibration
Explanation:
• Dorsal column conveys fine touch, proprioception, and vibration from the ipsilateral body.
• Pain/temp – spinothalamic.

questions.text: A patient reports feeling his amputated limb being touched when his face is stroked. This is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 
Cortical reorganization and plasticity
Explanation:
• Phantom limb sensation is due to cortical remapping – neighboring cortical areas take over deafferented areas, leading to referred sensations.

choices.text: Law of projection and labelled line principle

questions.text: A patient feels pain in his missing toe when the stump is touched. This can be explained by which of the following sensory principles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Law of projection and labelled line principle
Explanation:
• Law of projection: regardless of stimulation site along a pathway, sensation is felt at the receptor’s location.
• Labelled line principle: the nature of the sensation depends on the type of nerve fiber, not the stimulus type.

questions.text: Lesion of which structure in the Papez circuit is most likely to impair emotional memory?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mammillary bodies
Explanation:
• Papez circuit: hippocampus → fornix → mammillary bodies → anterior thalamus → cingulate gyrus → parahippocampal gyrus → hippocampus.
• Important for emotion-linked memory (limbic system).

questions.text: Which hypothalamic nucleus is the master regulator of circadian rhythm and is entrained by light?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Suprachiasmatic nucleus
Explanation:
• The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) receives light input from the retina → synchronizes melatonin release and biological clock.

questions.text: Electrical stimulation of which brain structure evokes autonomic and emotional signs of fear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Amygdala
Explanation:
• Amygdala is the fear and threat center, linking sensory stimuli to emotional responses.
• Lesions → loss of fear, disinhibited behavior (Klüver–Bucy syndrome).

choices.text: Closure of Na⁺ channels and hyperpolarization

questions.text: Light striking a rod photoreceptor leads to which of the following changes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Closure of Na⁺ channels and hyperpolarization
Explanation:
• Light activates rhodopsin → transducin → ↓cGMP → Na⁺ channels close → hyperpolarization → ↓glutamate release.

questions.text: A lesion in the lateral lemniscus would most affect which function?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hearing localization
Explanation:
• Lateral lemniscus carries auditory information bilaterally to the inferior colliculus, critical for sound localization.
• Frequency detection occurs at cochlear level.

questions.text: Which taste modality is sensed via ion channels rather than G-protein–coupled receptors (GPCRs)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sour
Explanation:
• Sour = H⁺ ions enter via ion channels.
• Sweet, bitter, and umami use GPCRs (T1R and T2R families).

questions.text: A drug that blocks L-type calcium channels will most directly affect which phase of the ventricular myocyte action potential?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Phase 2

Explanation:
• Phase 2 = plateau, due to Ca²⁺ influx via L-type channels balancing K⁺ efflux.
• Blocking these channels shortens AP duration and reduces contraction strength.

questions.text: A prolonged PR interval on ECG most likely indicates a delay in conduction through which structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

AV node

Explanation:
• PR interval = atrial depolarization + AV nodal delay.
• AV node delay allows time for ventricular filling.

choices.text: Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
Opening of mitral and tricuspid valves
Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves

questions.text: The first heart sound (S1) corresponds to which of the following cardiac events?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves

Explanation:
• S1 = AV valve closure → marks start of systole.

questions.text: A patient with tricuspid regurgitation would show which of the following JVP changes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Prominent v wave

Explanation:
• v wave = atrial filling against closed tricuspid valve.
• In tricuspid regurgitation, v wave is exaggerated due to backflow

questions.text: The dicrotic notch in the aortic pressure waveform represents:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Aortic valve closure

Explanation:
• Dicrotic notch = backflow causing aortic valve closure, seen in early diastole.

questions.text: Which of the following changes would increase cardiac oxygen consumption the most?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Increased contractility

Explanation:
• Tension-time index: myocardial O₂ demand increases most with contractility and afterload.
• Contractility increases active work done by the heart.

questions.text: In a patient with systemic vasoconstriction, a 50?crease in arteriole radius leads to what approximate change in blood flow?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Which of the following changes increases total peripheral resistance in a tissue bed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Closure of some parallel arterioles

Explanation:
• In parallel circuits, resistance decreases with more open paths.
• Closing vessels → ↑resistance.

questions.text: In an aneurysmal aortic segment, wall tension increases primarily due to which factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increased radius

Explanation:
• Laplace’s Law:
Tension = [Pressure x radius] / Wall thickness
→ ↑ radius → ↑wall tension → risk of rupture.

questions.text: Sudden standing from supine position activates which reflex to maintain blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Baroreceptor reflex

Explanation:
• ↓venous return → ↓BP → ↓baroreceptor firing → ↑sympathetic outflow → vasoconstriction, ↑HR.

questions.text: IV infusion rapidly increases venous return. Reflex increase in heart rate is mediated via:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stretch receptors in right atrium

Explanation:
• Bainbridge reflex: ↑venous return → RA stretch → ↑HR via vagal inhibition.

questions.text: Coronary blood flow is lowest during which phase of the cardiac cycle in the left ventricle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Systole

Explanation:
• Systolic compression of left coronary vessels reduces flow.
• Flow mainly occurs during diastole in the left ventricle.

questions.text: A patient undergoes cardiac catheterization to assess his left ventricular function prior to thoracic surgery. What is his ejection fraction, as determined from the left ventricular pressure-volume curve illustrated below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

0.54
Explanation:
The ejection fraction (EF) is equal to the stroke volume (SV) divided by the end-diastolic volume (EDV) and the stroke volume (SV) is equal to the end-diastolic volume (EDV) minus the end-systolic volume (ESV).
EF = SV/EDV = EDV – ESV/EDV
In this case, the end-diastolic volume is 130 mL and the end-systolic volume is 60 mL. Therefore, the ejection fraction is 70 mL/130 mL or 0.54.

questions.text: Three parallel arterioles arising from an artery and their respective resistances are given in the picture. Due to vasodilation, the resistance of Arteriole B decreases to 15 PRU, while A and C remain unchanged. What is the approximate percentage increase in total vascular conductance of the organ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

30 %

Explanation:

questions.text: A small arteriole normally has a radius of 1 mm. Due to autonomic regulation; the radius decreases by 50%. Assuming no change in pressure or viscosity, by approximately how much does the blood flow through the arteriole change?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Decreases by 94%
Explanation:

choices.text: Stimulates gastric acid secretion during cephalic phase
Stimulates migrating motor complex during fasting

questions.text: A 25-year-old fasting individual experiences rhythmic contractions in the stomach every 90 minutes. Which of the following best explains the physiological role of the hormone involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stimulates migrating motor complex during fasting

Explanation:
• Motilin is released cyclically during fasting and stimulates MMC, clearing the gut of residual food and bacteria.
• A: Gastrin/HCl related
• B: Motilin stimulates, not inhibits
• D: Segmentation is promoted by CCK, not motilin

questions.text: A patient with duodenal ulcer undergoes a test where secretin is administered. Which response confirms intact duodenal physiology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increased pancreatic bicarbonate secretion

Explanation:
• Secretin is released in response to acidic chyme in duodenum.
• Stimulates HCO₃⁻ secretion from pancreas and biliary duct.
• A: Secretin inhibits gastric acid
• C: Not direct action
• D: Somatostatin is not directly suppressed

choices.text: Contracts gallbladder and relaxes sphincter of Oddi

questions.text: A cholecystectomy patient is less efficient in digesting fats. Which of the following CCK effects best explains the problem?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Contracts gallbladder and relaxes sphincter of Oddi

Explanation:
• CCK is released by I cells in duodenum → promotes bile release and pancreatic enzyme secretion
• Without gallbladder, bile delivery is less efficient

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter predominantly mediates excitatory motor signals in the myenteric plexus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Acetylcholine

Explanation:
• ACh → major excitatory NT for gut motility
• NO → inhibitory
• Dopamine → reduces motility
• Somatostatin → inhibitory

choices.text: It is generated by smooth muscle
It determines the maximum frequency of contractions
It is absent in the colon

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the basal electrical rhythm in the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 It determines the maximum frequency of contractions

Explanation:
• BER is generated by Interstitial cells of Cajal
• Sets rhythmic depolarization pattern (not actual contraction)
• Smooth muscle contracts only when BER reaches threshold

questions.text: A patient with intracranial hypertension begins vomiting. This likely involves direct stimulation of which center?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Area postrema in medulla

Explanation:
• Area postrema is the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ), lacks BBB, sensitive to toxins/pressure
• Vagal centers execute the reflex but aren’t the initial trigger

choices.text: Voluntary relaxation of external anal sphincter
Local reflex via pelvic splanchnic nerves

questions.text: A patient with spinal cord injury above the sacral level cannot voluntarily defecate but has spontaneous bowel movements. Which mechanism remains intact?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Local reflex via pelvic splanchnic nerves

Explanation:
• The defecation reflex is spinal (S2–S4) mediated, involuntary reflex persists even if higher control is lost.

questions.text: A patient is treated with both ranitidine (H2 blocker) and vagotomy. Which cell is directly affected by both treatments?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Parietal cell

Explanation:
• Parietal cells are stimulated by:
o Vagus (via ACh, indirect via GRP → gastrin)
o Histamine (H₂ receptor)
• Blocking both shuts down acid secretion maximally

questions.text: In a patient with autoimmune gastritis, which step in vitamin B12 absorption is most likely impaired?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Formation of intrinsic factor–B12 complex

Explanation:
• Autoimmune gastritis destroys parietal cells, leading to loss of intrinsic factor → no IF-B12 complex → no absorption in terminal ileum

choices.text: Lack of vitamin C reduces Fe³⁺ conversion
Lack of gastric acid impairs Fe³⁺ to Fe²⁺ conversion
Iron transporters are absent in jejunum
Ferritin binding in colon is impaired

questions.text: A patient is found to have iron deficiency anemia post-gastrectomy. Which mechanism best explains this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lack of gastric acid impairs Fe³⁺ to Fe²⁺ conversion

Explanation:
• Acidic pH helps reduce ferric (Fe³⁺) to ferrous (Fe²⁺) → absorbable form in duodenum
• Gastrectomy → hypochlorhydria → ↓ Fe²⁺

choices.text: Loss of elastic recoil of alveoli

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with emphysema has a markedly increased functional residual capacity (FRC). What is the most likely explanation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Loss of elastic recoil of alveoli

Explanation:
• Emphysema → destruction of alveolar walls → ↓ elastic recoil → lungs “trap” more air → ↑ FRC
• A: Resistance affects airflow, not volume
• B: Emphysema increases compliance
• C: Not characteristic of emphysema

questions.text: During labored breathing in COPD, which of the following muscles contributes to active inspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Sternocleidomastoid

Explanation:
• Sternocleidomastoid and scalene assist in accessory inspiration
• A & B: Expiratory muscles
• D: Abdominal muscle → expiration

questions.text: A patient is mechanically ventilated. His end-tidal CO₂ (ETCO₂) is much lower than arterial CO₂ (PaCO₂). Which condition is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pulmonary embolism

Explanation:
• Pulmonary embolism → perfusion problem → ↑ physiological dead space
• ETCO₂ drops while PaCO₂ stays high → classic PE pattern
• B & C: Don’t cause this discrepancy directly
• D: Affects oxygen, not CO₂ difference

choices.text: Large volume change per small pressure
Small pressure change per large volume
Small volume change per large pressure
Equal volume change for all pressures

questions.text: In restrictive lung disease, lung compliance is decreased. Which pressure-volume change best reflects this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Small volume change per large pressure

Explanation:
• Compliance = ΔV / ΔP
• ↓ Compliance → need high pressure to cause even small volume change

questions.text: A neonate with congenital heart disease has normal ventilation but zero oxygenation improvement with 100% O₂. What is the most likely explanation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Intrapulmonary shunt

Explanation:
• In shunt: blood bypasses ventilated alveoli → no oxygenation even with 100% O₂
• A & B: Partial improvement expected
• C: High V/Q → dead space

questions.text: A 50-year-old smoker has an FEV1/FVC ratio of 55%. Which is the most consistent finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Increased residual volume

Explanation:
• FEV1/FVC <70% → obstructive pattern
• In COPD → air trapping → ↑ RV
• C: Seen in restrictive disease
• D: Emphysema reduces recoil

questions.text: A lesion in the pons results in prolonged inspiratory gasps with brief expirations (apneustic breathing). What center is likely damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pneumotaxic center

Explanation:
• Pneumotaxic center inhibits the apneustic center
• Damage → apneustic breathing pattern
• DRG/VRG are medullary (not pons)

questions.text: Which of the following changes is the most powerful stimulus for ventilation in normal individuals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Arterial PCO₂ increase

Explanation:
• Central chemoreceptors respond most to ↑ CO₂ (via pH drop)
• PO₂ affects peripheral chemoreceptors, but only when <60 mm Hg

questions.text: In which scenario is the Hering–Breuer inflation reflex is most significant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Deep inspiration during exercise

Explanation:
• Stretch receptors → inhibit inspiration during overinflation
• Protective in deep breaths, not active in quiet breathing

choices.text: Loss of response to metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: A patient becomes apneic following bilateral carotid body removal. What is the most immediate deficit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Loss of response to hypoxia

Explanation:
• Carotid bodies sense hypoxia (↓ PO₂)
• Central chemoreceptors detect CO₂/pH, not O₂

questions.text: The above figure shows three diﬀerent compliance curves (S, T, and U) for isolated lungs subjected to various transpulmonary pressures. Which of the following best describes the relative compliances for the three curves?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

S > T > U

questions.text: Assuming a respiratory rate of 12 breaths/min, calculate the minute ventilation.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

6 L / min
Explanation:

questions.text: A 67-year-old man has a solid tumor that pushes against an airway, partially obstructing air flow to the distal alveoli. Which point on the line of the O2-CO2 diagram above corresponds to the alveolar gas of these distal alveoli?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Read the image of O2 – Hb Dissociation curve given below. What are the approximate values of Hb saturation (% Hb-O2), PO 2, and O2 content for oxygenated blood leaving the lungs and reduced blood returning to the lungs from the tissues?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: Which time points on the below figure (V-Z) are associated with the highest P CO 2 of lung blood and highest PCO 2 of the neurons in the respiratory center?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: The basic mechanism of Cheyne-Stokes breathing can be aributed to a buildup of CO2 that stimulates overventilation, followed by a depression of the respiratory center because of a low PCO 2 of the respiratory neurons. It should be clear that the greatest depth of breathing occurs when the neurons of the respiratory center are exposed to the highest levels of CO2 (point W). This increase in breathing causes CO2 to be blown oﬀ, and thus the PCO 2 of the lung blood is at its lowest value at about point Y in the figure. The PCO 2 of the pulmonary blood gradually increases from point Y to point Z, reaching its maximum value at point V. Thus, it is the phase lag between the PCO 2 at the respiratory center and the PCO 2 of the pulmonary blood that leads to this type of breathing. The phase lag often occurs with left heart failure due to enlargement of the left ventricle, which increases the time required for blood to reach the respiratory center. Another cause of Cheyne-Stokes breathing is increased negative feedback gain in the respiratory control areas, which can be caused by head trauma, stroke, and other types of brain damage

choices.text: Decreased GFR due to reduced renal blood flow
Increased GFR due to increased glomerular capillary pressure
Decreased GFR due to mesangial contraction

questions.text: A patient is given a drug that preferentially constricts the efferent arteriole of the glomerulus. Which of the following is the most likely immediate effect on GFR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increased GFR due to increased glomerular capillary pressure

Explanation:
• Efferent arteriole constriction → ↑ pressure in glomerular capillaries → ↑ GFR (initially)
• A: RBF decreases, but GFR initially increases
• C: Mesangial cells not directly involved here
• D: There is an effect

choices.text: Increased FF due to increased GFR
Decreased FF due to decreased efferent arteriole resistance
No change in FF due to autoregulation
Increased FF due to decreased renal plasma flow

questions.text: A patient is given ACE inhibitors. Which of the following best describes their effect on filtration fraction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Decreased FF due to decreased efferent arteriole resistance

Explanation:
• FF = GFR / RPF
• ACE inhibitors dilate efferent arterioles → ↓ GFR, minimal change in RPF → ↓ FF

choices.text: Exceeding the maximal reabsorptive capacity of glucose transporters

questions.text: A diabetic patient with blood glucose of 300 mg/dL is noted to have glucosuria. Which of the following best explains the mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Exceeding the maximal reabsorptive capacity of glucose transporters

Explanation:
• Glucose is reabsorbed by SGLT-2 in PCT
• If plasma glucose > transport maximum (Tm) → glucosuria
• D: Threshold is normal; it’s just exceeded

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has a blood glucose level of 180 mg/dL, yet he shows glucose in urine. Which of the following is the most likely explanation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Defect in glucose transport proteins

Explanation:
• Normally, threshold ≈ 180 mg/dL
• Glucosuria at threshold suggests early saturation or mutated SGLT proteins (e.g., familial renal glucosuria)

questions.text: Which segment of the nephron is responsible for actively transporting NaCl into the interstitium and is impermeable to water, contributing to medullary hypertonicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Thick ascending limb

Explanation:
• Thick ascending limb (TAL): reabsorbs Na⁺, K⁺, Cl⁻ → diluting segment
• Impermeable to water → generates osmotic gradient for counter-current multiplier

questions.text: Which nephron segment has urea transporters regulated by ADH to increase urea reabsorption and aid in medullary hypertonicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Medullary collecting duct

Explanation:
• ADH upregulates UT-A1 and UT-A3 in medullary collecting duct
• Promotes urea recycling → ↑ medullary osmolarity → concentrates urine

questions.text: ABG: pH = 7.30, pCO₂ = 50 mmHg, HCO₃⁻ = 24 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely primary disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Respiratory acidosis

Explanation:
• pCO₂ ↑ (normal = 35–45)
• HCO₃⁻ normal = acute
• pH ↓ → primary respiratory acidosis

questions.text: In chronic metabolic acidosis, renal ammoniagenesis increases. What is the primary source of ammonia production in proximal tubules?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Glutamine

Explanation:
• Glutamine metabolism in PCT → NH₃ and α-ketoglutarate
• NH₃ buffers H⁺ in lumen → aids acid excretion

choices.text: Increased Na⁺ reabsorption in collecting duct

questions.text: A child with hypertension, metabolic alkalosis, and low renin and aldosterone is found to have a gain-of-function mutation in the ENaC channel. What best explains the pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased Na⁺ reabsorption in collecting duct

Explanation:
• Liddle syndrome: ↑ ENaC activity in collecting duct → Na⁺ reabsorption → ↑ volume, HTN → suppresses RAAS
• Also causes K⁺ and H⁺ loss → alkalosis

questions.text: A child presents with hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and normal blood pressure. Genetic testing shows a mutation in the Na⁺/K⁺/2Cl⁻ transporter. Which segment is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Thick ascending limb

Explanation:
• Bartter syndrome = defective NKCC2 in TAL → mimics loop diuretic
• Leads to salt wasting, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis without HTN (RAAS activation compensates)

choices.text: Activation of PKA and cAMP pathway
Increased GLUT-2 expression on plasma membrane
Increased GLUT-4 translocation to plasma membrane

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy receives a subcutaneous insulin injection after a glucose-rich meal. Which of the following best describes the immediate cellular mechanism in skeletal muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Increased GLUT-4 translocation to plasma membrane

Explanation:
Insulin promotes glucose uptake into skeletal muscle and adipose tissue via translocation of GLUT-4 transporters through tyrosine kinase receptor signaling.
• A: cAMP pathway is inhibited by insulin.
• B: GLUT-2 is found in liver and pancreatic β-cells, not muscle.
• D: Insulin activates, not inhibits, tyrosine kinase.

choices.text: Direct activation of osteoclasts by PTH
Indirect activation of osteoclasts via RANKL expression by osteoblasts
Inhibition of osteoblasts by vitamin D

questions.text: A patient with primary hyperparathyroidism has elevated serum calcium. Which mechanism best explains the bone resorption seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Indirect activation of osteoclasts via RANKL expression by osteoblasts

Explanation:
PTH stimulates osteoblasts to express RANKL, which activates osteoclast precursors, leading to bone resorption.
• A: PTH does not directly activate osteoclasts.
• B: Calcitonin opposes PTH.
• D: Vitamin D facilitates mineralization, not inhibition.

choices.text: Binding to nuclear receptors and regulating transcription

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman has weight loss, palpitations, and heat intolerance. Her TSH is suppressed, and free T4 is elevated. At the cellular level, thyroid hormones exert their effect by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Binding to nuclear receptors and regulating transcription

Explanation:
Thyroid hormones are lipophilic and bind to nuclear receptors, altering gene expression.
• A/B: TSH acts via cAMP, but not T3/T4.
• D: Incorrect mechanism.

questions.text: A man with a pheochromocytoma has episodic hypertension and palpitations. Which of the following best explains his elevated blood pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Norepinephrine binding to α1-adrenergic receptors

Explanation:
Pheochromocytomas secrete excessive norepinephrine, which activates α1 receptors causing vasoconstriction and hypertension.
• A: β2 causes vasodilation
• C: Dopamine acts primarily in kidneys
• D: RAS may be secondary but not primary in pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: In a patient undergoing surgery, cortisol levels rise. What is the primary cardiovascular effect of cortisol during stress?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased vascular responsiveness to catecholamines

Explanation:
Cortisol enhances the α1 receptor sensitivity to catecholamines → maintains BP during stress.
• A: Aldosterone works independently.
• B/D: Opposite of cortisol effects.

choices.text: GH binding to GPCRs on chondrocytes

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with gigantism has elevated IGF-1. The growth-promoting effects of GH are mediated predominantly via:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hepatic production of IGF-1

Explanation:
GH stimulates liver to produce IGF-1, which promotes bone and tissue growth.
• A/D: GH acts indirectly on growth tissues.
• C: Not the main mechanism.

questions.text: A patient with head trauma presents with polyuria and polydipsia. Urine remains dilute even after water deprivation but concentrates after desmopressin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Central diabetes insipidus

Explanation:
Desmopressin response indicates ADH deficiency, i.e., central DI.
• C: Nephrogenic DI would not respond.
• A: Presents with water retention.
• D: May concentrate partially with water deprivation.

choices.text: Inhibits calcium absorption from the gut
Stimulates intestinal expression of calcium-binding proteins

questions.text: A child with rickets is found to have low serum calcium and phosphate. Which mechanism best describes how vitamin D corrects this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stimulates intestinal expression of calcium-binding proteins

Explanation:
Calcitriol (active Vit D) increases intestinal Ca²⁺ and phosphate absorption via calbindin D expression.
• A/B: Opposite of Vit D action
• D: Not its function

questions.text: Which of the following hormones uses the cAMP second messenger system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ACTH

Explanation:
ACTH uses Gs protein → cAMP → PKA
• A: GH uses JAK-STAT
• B: Nuclear receptor
• D: Tyrosine kinase

questions.text: A hormone binds a Gq-coupled receptor, activating phospholipase C. Which of the following second messengers is subsequently increased?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

IP3
Explanation:
Gq → PLC → IP3 & DAG → Ca²⁺ release
• A: Gs pathway
• C: Used by NO/ANP
• D: Not a second messenger

choices.text: Excessive androgens from the adrenal gland

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with hypothalamic amenorrhea has low levels of GnRH, LH, FSH, and estradiol. Which of the following best explains the absence of ovulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Failure of LH surge
Explanation: GnRH deficiency → ↓LH → no mid-cycle LH surge → no ovulation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man has infertility despite normal testosterone levels. Which testicular cell dysfunction most likely explains his low sperm count?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sertoli cells
Explanation: Sertoli cells support spermatogenesis, secrete inhibin B, and maintain the blood-testis barrier.

questions.text: A 17-year-old phenotypic female has primary amenorrhea. She has sparse axillary hair and a blind-ending vagina. Karyotype is 46,XY. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Androgen insensitivity syndrome
Explanation: Complete AIS = 46,XY with nonfunctional androgen receptors → female phenotype, no uterus, undescended testes.

questions.text: A rise in estrogen during the late follicular phase leads to a surge in which hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 LH
Explanation: High estrogen → positive feedback on anterior pituitary → LH surge → ovulation.

questions.text: During the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle, progesterone is responsible for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Endometrial secretory transformation
Explanation: Progesterone converts proliferative endometrium into secretory type to support implantation.

questions.text: Which hormone, secreted by syncytiotrophoblasts, maintains corpus luteum function during early pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
Explanation: hCG mimics LH to maintain corpus luteum and progesterone production until placenta takes over.

questions.text: Spermatogenesis occurs in the seminiferous tubules and requires optimal temperature and hormonal support. Which hormone provides negative feedback to the anterior pituitary to regulate FSH?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Inhibin B
Explanation: Inhibin B is secreted by Sertoli cells and inhibits FSH production.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy has ambiguous genitalia and hypertension. 17-hydroxyprogesterone is elevated. What enzyme deficiency best explains his findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

11β-hydroxylase
Explanation: 11β-hydroxylase deficiency → ↓cortisol, ↓aldosterone, ↑11-DOC (mineralocorticoid) → HTN and androgen excess.

questions.text: A postpartum woman is able to breastfeed her infant despite high prolactin levels during pregnancy not inducing lactation. What hormonal change postpartum permits milk secretion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Decrease in estrogen and progesterone
Explanation: Estrogen and progesterone inhibit milk secretion despite high prolactin. Their fall after delivery → lactation starts.

choices.text: Decreased negative feedback from estrogen and inhibin
Elevated LH stimulating the anterior pituitary

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with hot flashes and irregular periods. Lab shows ↑FSH, ↓estradiol. Which is the physiological basis for the high FSH?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Decreased negative feedback from estrogen and inhibin
Explanation: Ovarian failure → ↓estrogen and ↓inhibin → ↑FSH and LH due to lack of feedback inhibition.
